EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OF RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR CLINTON, MISSISSIPPI BRIGHTON WATER TREATMENT FACILITY

I.  Introduction

The water treatment facility located in Clinton, Mississippi's Brighton Subdivision, known as the "Brighton Well," provides drinking water for some of the inhabitants and businesses located in the city of Clinton, MS.  The city of Clinton has a population of approximately 26,405 people and a number of businesses, schools, industrial facilities, and recreational areas.

II.  Regulated Substance and Covered Process

In order to comply with Federal and State regulations concerning water treatment, chlorine is used for the disinfection of drinking water.  There is up to 4,000 lbs. of chlorine connected in process at any given time, therefore, the Brighton Well Treatment Plant falls into Level II of the EPA's Risk Management Program Regulations.

III.  Emergency Response and Policies

The City of Clinton Department of Public Works is committed to reliably providing quality drinking water that conforms to all local, state, and federal water quality standards to the inhabitants of Clinton, Mississippi with public safety as a top priority.  The City of Clinton Department of Public Works has coordinated emergency response activities with several emergency response agencies including the local fire department, police department, and the Hinds County Emergency Operations Center.

IV.  Accidental Prevention Program

The facility's accident prevention program includes each of the elements required by the Risk Management Program regulations.

V.  Safety Information

The City of Clinton Department of Public Works has gathered the necessary documentation of safety information on the covered chlorine process including a chlorine material safety data sheet, maximum intended inventory of equipment in which chlorine is stored or processed, safe upper and lower temperatures, pressures, and flowrates in all of the equipment in which chlorine is stored or processed, equi

pment specifications, and applicable codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the process.

VI.  Hazard Review

A hazard review was conducted on the covered process to identify all hazards and potential hazards associated with the process.  The results of the review were used to determine the appropriate safeguards needed to prevent or mitigate a release. Reviews were conducted on 9/22/06 and 4/10/09.

VII.  Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures have been in place at the City of Clinton Department of Public Works for several years.  These procedures address daily and periodic duties of plant operators as well as emergency situations.

VIII.  Maintenance Procedures

Written maintenance procedures have been in place at the City of Clinton Department of Public Works for several years.  Included in these procedures are inspections, a preventative maintenance schedule, and logs for all of these activities.

IX.  Five-year Accident History

No serious accidents have occurred at this facility within the last five years.

X.  Changes Planned to Improve Safety

The City of Clinton feels that there are none needed at this time.
